awd_titl_txt: The Chemistry of Oxidation Flow Reactors (OFR) and the Sources of Semivolatile and Intermediate Volatility Secondary Organic Aerosol (SOA) Precursors in Recent NSF Field Studies
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will inform the use of Oxidation Flow Reactors (OFR) in the study of atmospheric chemistry.  OFR are used to study the formation of secondary organic aerosol (SOA) in the atmosphere.  Experimental and modeling investigations of the use of the OFR will help to determine their representativeness to understanding chemical reactions in the atmosphere.

This effort addresses two research questions: (1) What is the representativeness of OFR chemistry compared to the atmosphere and large environmental chambers, and how can it be optimized?  (2) What are the key SOA precursors for OH oxidation of ambient air in biogenic environments?  The project includes modeling and laboratory studies to simulate observational measurements from recent NSF-supported field campaigns. This research will provide critically-needed information on the usefulness, interpretation, and best practices of the OFR technique that is being adopted rapidly by the atmospheric science community.  This effort also will help place firmer constraints on the key precursors, pathways and anthropogenic-biogenic interactions controlling SOA formation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Overview

Secondary organic aerosol (SOA) is a major aerosol component, with important impacts on human health and climate. However, SOA sources are poorly understood, and evaluation of models with field data suffers from the confounding effects of atmospheric variability. Use of Oxidation Flow Reactors (OFR) in the lab and field has been growing extremely rapidly as a tool to study SOA formation. Under support of this grant, we performed a range of modeling and experimental investigations to clarify and optimize the representativity of OFR chemistry to the atmosphere, developed several publicly-available tools, software, and parameterizations to aid in OFR experimental planning and interpretation, and helped build a strong support community for implementation in atmospheric chemistry research.

Intellectual Merit

OFRs may soon be the main type of atmospheric simulation reactor in use. Thus, there is a critical need to better understand the chemistry and emerging field results from OFRs. Despite extensive field, laboratory, and modeling work by our group and others at the time of our proposal, questions lingered in the research community about how representative OFR chemistry is vs. the atmosphere and chambers.

In this project we worked to address the major research question: 

What is the representativeness of OFR chemistry compared to the atmosphere and large environmental chambers, and how can it be optimized? 

We addressed this question primarily via modeling.

(a) We modeled (with the KinSim software) the fate of organic peroxy radicals (RO2) across a wide range of OFR input and operating conditions and compared to a range of atmospheric and chamber conditions. We identified deviations between RO2 fate in OFR vs. the atmosphere and investigated methods to reduce these differences, and to make a single RO2 fate dominant. (Peng et al., 2019)

(b) We investigated the complete oxidation chemistry of a biogenic (isoprene), an aromatic (m-xylene), and several alkane compounds under a variety of OFR, chamber, and atmospheric conditions using the GECKO-A fully explicit model, with a focus on evolution of OH reactivity (Peng et al., 2021).

We recognized several gaps in readily accessible experimental and modeling tools for investigating OFRs and SOA chemistry. Thus, we adopted development, applications, dissemination, and support of such tools within this project. These include a powerful, user-friendly kinetic simulator (KinSim; gas/aerosol chemistry, evaporation/condensation; Peng & Jimenez, 2019), software for exploring GECKO-A outputs and loading mechanisms into KinSim, a photolysis calculator, and multiple estimator equations for OFR parameters.

We conducted additional analyses and developed tools/frameworks directly relevant to improving understanding of SOA in the laboratory, field, and modeling including:

  • A broad survey of anthropogenic SOA, and its contributions to SOA, dependencies among megacities, and modeled their attribution to mortality rates. (Nault et al., 2021)

  • Chamber studies and developed new experimental modeling approaches to quantify gas-particle accommodation and activity coefficients for partitioning of oxidized organic compounds into a wide range of seed particles types. (Liu et al., 2019; 2020)

  • Evaluated gas-phase wall loss for "batch" vs "continuous flow" chambers and associated dependencies of SOA yields. (Krechmer et al., 2020)

  • Modeled evolution and dependencies of isoprene-epoxydiol-derived SOA (IEPOX-SOA) under different socioeconomic pathways (climate scenarios) and modeling frameworks. (Jo et al., 2021)

  • Evaluated and improved methods for detection of aerosol organic nitrates with aerosol mass spectrometry, and explored trends in apportionment within the atmosphere. (Day et al., AMT, 2022)

  • Conducted chamber experiments, coupled with explicit modeling, to study the amount, composition, and pathways for SOA from oxidation of monoterpenes (α-pinene and Δ-carene) by nitrate radical under different RO2 fate regimes. (Day et al., JPC, 2022)

  • Conducted a systematic survey of parameters relevant to SOA formation and the overlap between relevant global ambient conditions and laboratory chamber studies. (Porter et al., 2021).

  • Investigated feasibility of using polymer tubing types to separate compounds over the volatility range relevant to SOA formation. Results show promise for quantifying contributions to SOA formation by volatility (Morris et al., in prep.). 

Broader impacts

We released the powerful, easy-to-use KinSim simulator publicly, and published a paper describing it in J. Chem. Ed. We worked with colleagues to implement it in graduate and undergraduate courses. We offered tutorials on OFR operation and chemistry at major conferences. At least 39 published peer-reviewed papers have used KinSim to date. Many researchers (>250, 16+ countries) have joined the KinSim user community, including >50 using it for teaching. Several students and postdocs have been trained on state-of-the-art methods. We have publicly disseminated software tools developed for wide use in analyses and publications beyond our group. We have presented results at multiple major conferences and led/coauthored 33 publications, including a review of OFR radical chemistry in Chem. Soc. Rev. (Peng & Jimenez, 2020). Overall, the body of work supported by this grant provides important contributions to the understanding of and tools available for studying atmospheric chemistry and SOA formation, particularly with OFRs in the laboratory and field.
